ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom classes, asynchronous activities over Canvas and Voicethread

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed speaking, reading, listening and writing skills.

I became so much better at speaking and understanding Levantine Arabic. This is the first time in all my years of Arabic that I've been able to comprehend most of what I hear in random videos online and actually pick up new vocabulary from watching a TV show. I got new vocabulary, basics of Levantine grammar, and access to many different resources that will be helpful in my future study of Arabic.
introduction to levantine arabic, cultural insights, grammar
learned basic words and phrases in shaami, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was great! Though it was via zoom, Professor Al-Ani kept us engaged. The assignments were creative and the format of the class aided to the learning experience.
I wish we'd had more conversation time.

strengths: having synchronous sessions three times a week was helpful, feedback and expectations were clear
improvement: maybe more vocabulary/grammar quizzes (like vocab quizzes per chapter)

Strengths: very interactive and the teacher tries very hard to make sure that everyone is engaged

Weaknesses: caters to more advanced students in shaami; could be better if the pace of the class was slower, if we went over reading material in class and had actual lessons in class, learned conjugations, etc. Would benefit from the instructor teaching more rather than leaving the work to students to learn themselves outside of class

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Sarab was very good at using all kinds of online tools: Canvas, Zoom, Voicethread, etc.

success: use of voicethread, synchronous sessions and asynchronous work, engagement with cultural and popular media (music and television)
improvement: more understanding of students' personal circumstances during the pandemic, including that webcams cannot always be on
I enjoyed the 2 asynchronous days, to prevent zoom fatigue

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Depends. It is difficult if you have never been exposed to shaami before, as it doesn't really go over the basics. Easy if you know shaami
